Be it for treating common colds, fatal fever 'dengue' to chronic illnesses, there is an [Ayurvedic cure](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/ayurvedic-cure) for all. But if you visit an [allopathy](https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/topic/allopathy) doctor, he will rarely prescribe an Ayurvedic medicine and the logic is simple - legally a doctor should prescribe his own system of medicine and not something he hasn't studied. Even the Delhi Medical Council system announced that no allopathy doctor should prescribe Ayurvedic medicine and called it a punishable offense. Having said that, many allopathy doctors see promise in the Ayurvedic science and have been trying ways to integrate them into their mainstream medicine. Disorders like liver, arthritis, cough cold, piles as well as kidney stones are some examples of common ailments that have witnessed promising results with Ayurvedic medicines. As part of an integrative approach to health, Medanta will now be giving modern medicine and Ayurveda combined treatment in collaboration with AyurVAID hospitals. Dr Naresh Trehan, chairman and MD, Medanta the Medicity, said that while modern medicine and techniques treat various health conditions, they have side effects and are expensive too. On the other hand, Ayurveda has shown great promise in making the body strong to fight ailments by stimulating one's immune system; it is also a cheaper treatment. Talking in detail about the plan, Dr Trehan shared, "We will be developing innovative treatment techniques by combining Ayurveda and Allopathy for patients who are battling various diseases.
